tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a product page using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper alignment and spacing. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).

Write down 5 pain points from your own experiences with collaboration and communication in design teams. Analyze each point and think about how you can improve it. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/teslers-law).

Design a minimalistic logo for a fictional company using the principles of Aesthetic-Usability Effect. Consider color, typography, and imagery. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect)

Create a user journey map for a typical user interacting with your company's website or app. Identify pain points and areas for improvement using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics).

Develop a basic product strategy document for a hypothetical product, including target audience, features, and unique selling points. Focus on clarity and concision. (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/laws-of-ux).

Conduct 2 usability testing sessions with friends or family members, using the Hick's Law principle to guide your questioning. Analyze the results and think about how you can apply them to real-world design challenges.
Create a comprehensive product roadmap for a company, including short-term and long-term goals, key performance indicators (KPIs), and potential risks. Focus on clarity and stakeholder buy-in.
Develop a collaboration strategy document for your design team, outlining roles, responsibilities, and communication channels. Reference Tesler's Law to inform your approach.
Design an error message for a common user mistake using the 10 Usability Heuristics (Reference: https://nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics).
Create a comprehensive design system documentation, outlining your company's design principles, patterns, and components. Focus on clarity and consistency.
Develop a case study of a successful product or service redesign using the Laws of UX framework (Reference: https://lawsofux.com).

Conduct 2 user interviews with industry experts or thought leaders in your field, using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework to guide your questioning. Analyze the results and think about how you can apply them to real-world design challenges.

resources.readup: As a Practitioner UX designer, remember that your skills are not set in stone - continuous learning and self-improvement can elevate you to the next level. Focus on bridging gaps in User Research & Validation (68/100) and Product Thinking & Strategy (54/100), as these areas will significantly impact the success of your projects.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Applying Hick's Law to Improve Navigation
topics.summary: Hick's Law states that the time taken to make a decision decreases as the number of options increases. As a Practitioner, apply this law to optimize navigation menus and reduce cognitive load.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing websites with complex navigation menus and calculate the average time it takes for users to find what they're looking for using Hick's Law
Design and test 2 alternative navigation menu designs that adhere to Hick's Law, measuring a 25% reduction in cognitive load
Conduct A/B testing on 1 website with a new navigation design, comparing the results to the original design

topics.name: Creating an Aesthetic-Usability Effect in Visual Design
topics.summary: The Aesthetic-Usability Effect states that users are more likely to engage with designs that are visually appealing. As a Practitioner, apply this principle to create an aesthetically pleasing design that also meets usability standards.
practice_points: Design 3 visual concepts for a new product feature using the Aesthetic-Usability Effect as a guiding principle
Conduct user testing on 2 existing designs and provide feedback on how to improve their aesthetic appeal while maintaining usability
Create a mood board with 5 design inspirations that incorporate the Aesthetic-Usability Effect, and use it as a reference for future design projects

topics.name: Conducting User Research Using the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: The Jobs-to-be-Done framework helps identify user needs and motivations. As a Practitioner, apply this framework to conduct user research and validate design decisions.
practice_points: Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document findings on user motivations and pain points
Create a user persona based on research findings from 1 previous project, incorporating insights from the Jobs-to-be-Done framework
Design and conduct an online survey to validate assumptions about user behavior related to a specific product feature
